turn.0: ELI5: what exactly does the square root of a number represent?
turn.1: I take it you don't do much math. Square roots are useful in solving many equations, and squares (the opposite of a square root) occur quite often in physics and the sciences.
turn.2: I do a lot of math (sort of), but it’s excel equations and I’ve never bothered to understand why I would divide a number by the square root to get a statistical analysis.  So ya, I’ve always let the computer think for me.  Thanks
turn.3: I'm not insulting you; squares and square roots and such aren't useful for everyone.
turn.4: I’m not offended. I asked cause I clearly don’t understand the relevance.
turn.5: Ah. I've had the (mis?)fortune of completely avoiding statistics and spreadsheet math. Given my field, I've been bombarded with squares and square roots for most of my life, so I was just a little bit baffled that you hadn't had a similar experience.
turn.6: Ya those of us that have the luxury of spreadsheets often learn a formula in Excel and never really know why each piece is relevant. I'm trying to change that for myself so I can make Excel a more useful tool for me.
turn.7: Interesting! May I ask what you actually do with those spreadsheets? Do you do data processing?
turn.8: Forecasting/demand planning, inventory management. There’s software that does it all for you but I feel like I could be a better forecaster if I didn’t rely on the software as much. Most forecasters I know just ensure the data in their system is loaded accurately and press play and barely, if ever, question it.
